author: Kimberly Fornek
title: Hinsdale Hospital closes blood center, outsources its supply - The Doings Hinsdale
text:
Hinsdale Hospital has closed its blood collection center and will buy all the blood it needs from an outside vendor.
"We have weighed this decision for the past several years," Michael Murrill, chief operating officer of AMITA Health Adventist Medical Center, Hinsdale, wrote in a memo to staff. "We were one of the few hospitals that still had a blood donation center on site."
Hinsdale Hospital was the only Adventist hospital in the area to have a blood collection center, hospital officials said.
"Over time, hospitals were no longer able to sustain this service, because it became more cost effective to outsource it," Murrill stated. "We estimate a savings of more than $269,000 annually by purchasing blood from an outside vendor."
The need for blood was much greater than the Adventist Lab Partners Blood Center, operating in Elmwood Hall, at 121 Elm St., next to Hinsdale Hospital, could provide, Murrill said. LifeSource already was providing the majority of blood the hospital uses.

(Michael Joyce) Previously, and for the past 30 years or more, about 20 percent of the blood used at Adventist Hinsdale, La Grange Memorial, Bolingbrook and GlenOaks hospitals came from people who donated their blood at the blood center at Hinsdale Hospital, according to hospital officials and information on the hospital website.
But at the end of August, Hinsdale's blood donor center closed its doors.
"We have many people in the community who have donated blood for many years, and we are so thankful to these donors who have so graciously gave blood whenever needed," Murrill said. "We are working with LifeSource on finding new options for these donors. The goal is to not lose these donors."
Carl Panek is one of those dedicated donors. He donated blood in Hinsdale every two months for a good 30 years, he said.
He planned to donate platelets last month, but when he called to make an appointment, to his surprise, he got a recording saying the donor center was closed.
Panek, chairman of the Westchester blood program, will continue to donate blood. In fact, a blood drive is scheduled for 8 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday in the Westchester Community Center, at 10201 Bond St.
But Panek will miss the staff at the Hinsdale donor center.

Almost all of the staff members continue to work in other jobs at the hospital or they opted to go elsewhere, said Julie Busch, the hospital's assistant vice president of communications.
"The manager was laid off, but has since returned in another full-time role, and a newly hired recruiter was laid off and provided with severance," Busch said.
For the time being, the space vacated by the blood center will be used for offices. No long-term plans have been decided for the building, Busch said.
